Maybe there should be a bot that automatically bans whoever posts a telegram link

Do we need to have a rule about when the html spec can rely on a w3c spec? They're wildly unstable compared to what the html spec is supposed to be.

I'd say it should need to be in a CR or ready to ship/already shipping in a browser?
Luke Warlow: I think we have mainly found the CSS WG to be fairly unreliable. What else?
content.formatted_body: Luke Warlow: I think we have mainly found the CSS WG to be fairly unreliable. What else?

content.body: Well I was being general because technically the same applies to them all. But yes really it's them.
* Well I was being general because technically the same applies to them all (none are living standards). But yes really it's them.

m.new_content.body: Well I was being general because technically the same applies to them all (none are living standards). But yes really it's them.

content.body: Yeah, I don't know. https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/1967 is still a mess as far as I can tell, for instance, eight years old now. TabAtkins thoughts on this?
content.formatted_body: Yeah, I don't know. https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/1967 is still a mess as far as I can tell, for instance, eight years old now. TabAtkins thoughts on this?

content.body: Luke Warlow: at least for the parts I was involved in (CSS/WebPerf) we tried to keep the integration hooks themselves relatively stable. It's mostly "hooks" to call into the W3C specs to make things in these specs work (e.g. spin the view-transition algos) rather than having HTML "rely" on them though.
content.formatted_body: Luke Warlow: at least for the parts I was involved in (CSS/WebPerf) we tried to keep the integration hooks themselves relatively stable. It's mostly "hooks" to call into the W3C specs to make things in these specs work (e.g. spin the view-transition algos) rather than having HTML "rely" on them though.

content.body: I'm not sure, the Rendering section is fairly big and that was most recently impacted by these shenanigans. (Same for the pseudo-class example I gave, of which some would need some integration if they are agreed upon as sketched.)

> <@annevk:matrix.org> I'm not sure, the Rendering section is fairly big and that was most recently impacted by these shenanigans. (Same for the pseudo-class example I gave, of which some would need some integration if they are agreed upon as sketched.)

interactivity property integration was somewhat the same too, but didn't end up getting merged
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:matrix.org
I'm not sure, the Rendering section is fairly big and that was most recently impacted by these shenanigans. (Same for the pseudo-class example I gave, of which some would need some integration if they are agreed upon as sketched.)
interactivity property integration was somewhat the same too, but didn't end up getting merged

content.body: Any other examples? Being specific helps
